pr_title: LUCENE-9142 Refactor IntSet operations for determinize

timeline.bodyText: This is a really bad hash, to be honest.... What is this constructor even used for? It's really sneaky as it allows changes to the content of a "frozen" set of values?
timeline.author: dweiss

replies.bodyText: It's a shortcut for the other constructor, uses the same calculation for hash that is in SortedIntSet.calculateHash, but specialized down to a single value. I'll see if we can easily drop this code since I agree that it adds complexity for maintaners.
replies.author: madrob

replies.bodyText: oh, ok. drop it; the less code to understand the better. I don't think it'll be a particular gain here.
replies.author: dweiss

timeline.bodyText: I think the hashCode should be private to the abstract class and anything else should call hashCode() (including equals method). Then subclasses that are mutable could return true hashCode of their content (cached or computed).
timeline.author: dweiss

replies.bodyText: In addition, fields that are initialized in constructors and never changed should always be declared final.
replies.author: uschindler

timeline.bodyText: If it's just for debugging then I'd just use a stream and join the values there, it's a one-liner. Space after for(
timeline.author: dweiss

timeline.bodyText: isn't there a futurearrays method that does this in a single step (without intermediate zeroed int[])?
timeline.author: dweiss

replies.bodyText: Arrays.copyOf does it in two steps, same as here. FutureArrays has compare, equals, and mismatch that I see?
replies.author: madrob

replies.bodyText: You look at Java code but the difference is that Array.copyOf is (I believe) an jvm intrinsic so it should be replaced with a more optimized code. The pair of allocation+arraycopy should as well be optimized for that matter but it requires execution graph analysis and copyOf is straightforward.
replies.author: dweiss

timeline.bodyText: Hmm does it really need to be public?  I thought it's only the java sources in this package that use it?
timeline.author: mikemccand

timeline.bodyText: How come the code didn't need/use stale before?
timeline.author: mikemccand

replies.bodyText: Because it didn't track whether the cached hash code was stale and relied on the caller to do it. I feel like it is more clear to manage it internally.
replies.author: madrob

replies.bodyText: oh, found the replacement we should use: ArrayUtil.copyOfSubArray
replies.author: dweiss

timeline.bodyText: Isn't the array discarded as soon as we switch over to the map (so how could it be out of sync)?
timeline.author: mikemccand

replies.bodyText: The array is used for equality comparison.
replies.author: madrob

timeline.bodyText: Hmm why did we mark this API forbidden again?
timeline.author: mikemccand

replies.bodyText: Because copyOf was considered trappy -- the new length can be larger than original size of the input array (and is then null or zero padded)... I'm not sure it's worth having System.arraycopy instead... Maybe we could have a utility method that assert-verifies newLength <= length and uses Arrays.copyOf. Not sure.
replies.author: dweiss

timeline.bodyText: We don't need @Test annotations -- LuceneTestCase runner knows test* methods are tests.
timeline.author: mikemccand

replies.bodyText: I think you can remove these @Test annotations?
replies.author: mikemccand

timeline.bodyText: Would be nice to use a native map from HPPC instead -- does HPPC have a sorted map?  Hmm, but this is core, and we don't have any dependencies in Lucene's core :)
timeline.author: mikemccand

timeline.message:
LUCENE-9142 Refactor SortedIntSet for equality

Split SortedIntSet into a class heirarchy to make comparisons to
FrozenIntSet more meaningful. Use Arrays.equals for more efficient
comparison.

LUCENE-9142 Refactor SortedIntSet for equality

Split SortedIntSet into a class heirarchy to make comparisons to
FrozenIntSet more meaningful. Use Arrays.equals for more efficient
comparison.

timeline.bodyText: Could we rename to getArray?  asArray makes me think it might make a copy ...
timeline.author: mikemccand

replies.bodyText: In the case of SortedIntSet, it might make a copy, I wanted to leave it flexible for the underlying implementation on how to handles this. Renaming to getArray makes sense though.
replies.author: madrob
